Faced with impoverishment, her yield will be less this year if she does not do something. To address this, she requests a loan of $400 for the purchase of fertilizer and insecticide. This will increase her sales in order to better provide the necessities for her family.

Translated from French by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame K. Koato Hodé est une jeune femme mariée et mère de cinq (05) enfants. Son âge lui confère un dynamisme dans son activité. Très endurante, elle a une passion pour le jardinage qu’elle exerce depuis près de 8 ans. Le revenu qu’elle en tire quoique insignifiant lui permet de contribuer largement aux charges du ménage.

Devant l’appauvrissement du sol, son rendement sera moins cette année s’elle n’arrive pas à rien faire. Pour ce faire, elle sollicite un financement de $400 pour l’achat d’engrais et d’insecticide. Ceci augmentera son chiffre d’affaire afin de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide in order to improve the yield of her gardens.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is married with 7 children, is 48 years old, and comes from Shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells electronics and has been in business since 200. She now needs a loan of $875 to buy more electronics to sell.

loans.use: To buy more electronics for sale

loans.name: Luqueñas Group

texts.en:
The scent of freshly cut firewood fills the air of the courtyard at the home where the women of the communal bank ‘Luqueñas’ are gathered for their loan approval meeting. Half are seated on benches maD. from scrap lumber, the others perched on stumps yet to be cut to smaller pieces. All wait eagerly, with smiles of hope and confidence. This will be their second loan, and having just successfully paid back their first in full, they are expecting a slight increase in funds.

The women have various businesses. About half specialize in weaving and crocheting traditional clothing native to the region, primarily ‘huipiles’, a woven blouse that can take up to three months to produce. They will invest their loan in thread and yarn, which they purchase at a market in the town of Santiago D. Atitlán, about an hour bus riD. away. Others sell products from catalogues, such as shoes, clothing, jewelry, and perfume. They will use their loans to place purchases in bulk for items to have on hand that they know sell well. This way they can save money on shipping costs as well as the P. item cost. Those who don’t weave or sell products have businesses buying and selling corn and beans, two staple foods of the region. They travel to Santiago D. Atitlán once a week, purchase large amounts of corn and beans, and bring them back to their town of San Lucas to sell in the market or to regular customers.

All of the women have families that they are taking care of. Some have as many as nine children living at home, and they are working very hard to proviD. not only food and shelter but also a good education for all their kids. When asked if the loans help them accomplish this goal, there is a resounding ‘yes!’ from a previously timid crowd. They all start laughing and chattering away about their happiness to be part of their bank, and about the positive impact it has had on their lives so far. One woman looks up and says ‘we’re taking out another loan, aren’t we?!’ The seventeen women are asking for a loan of 38,115 quetzales (about $4975), ranging from $150 to $400 P. person.

loans.use: To purchase thread for weaving, corn and beans to sell, and to invest in home product sales

loans.name: Magdalena Asunción

texts.es:
Mrs. B. U., primary school teacher, single mother of 3 married older children, to support herself she has worked as a primary school teacher in the New Horizons School located in the Penitentiary System of Juigalpa for 6 years for a low entry level salary, in addition she sells cosmetics to coworkers and colleagues, this has enabled her to succeed in this stage of her life.  Nowadays she runs her business in a traveling manner selling products (perfumes, creams, lotions, etc.) a few years ago she decided to begin this business to obtain another income to support her home since she is a single mother and has been able to further her family while playing a double role as mother and father to her 3 children, with this loan from AFODENIC she will be able to consolidate and strengthen her inventory and be able to continue this activity as a work alternative that will allow her to achieve more goals in her life.

 Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. B. U., maestra de educacion primaria, soltera, madre de 3 hijos mayores casados, para su autosostenimiento labora como maestra de primaria en la Escuela Nuevos Horizontes ubicada en el Sistema Penitenciario de Juigalpa desde hace 6 años por el bajo ingreso salarial del sector , adicionalmente vende  cosmeticos a compañeros de trabajo, colegas y clientela domicialiar, lo que le ha permitido salir adelante en esta etapa de su vida.  

Actualmente ejerce su negocio de forma ambulante vendiendo productos (perfumes, cremas, lociones, etc), decidio emprender este negocio para obtener otros ingresos despues de su salario para sostener su hogar ya que es soltera desde hace varios años habiendo logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos teniendo doble roll familiar, de padre y madre en la formacion de sus 3 hijos; con financiamiento de AFODENIC ha logrado consolidar cierto inventario, el que pretende reforzar con la presente solicitud de financiamiento y mantener esta actividad como alternativa de trabajo que le permita lograr nuevas metas en su vida.

loans.use: To purchase perfumes, creams and lotions.

loans.name: Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Auxiliadora is a single woman, and along with her children is struggling to get ahead in life. She lives in the Nicaraguan Department of Nueva Guinea. She works as a baker, and also receives other income from field work, selling dairy products, and fattening swine.

She is a member of the cooperative COASCEMVIDE, is hardworking and entrepreneurial and needs some help in order to improve her living conditions. Auxiliadora is asking for this loan over 24 months to invest in the construction of her kitchen because it is in poor condition and she needs to improve it.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Auxiliadora es una mujer soltera, luchadora para salir adelante con sus hijos. Habita en el departamento de Nueva Guinea. Trabaja realizando hornado, también recibe otros ingreso del trabajo en el campo, vende productos lacteos y engorda cerdo.

Esta señora es miembro de la cooperativa COASCEMVIDE, ella es una mujer trabajadora, emprededora que necesita salir adelante para mejorar su condiciones de vida. Doña Auxiliadora está solicitando su crédito para invertirlo en la construción de la cocina, ya que está en malas condiciones y necesita mejorarla, a un plazo de 24 meses.

loans.use: Construction of Kitchen in her Home

loans.name: Latofat

texts.ru:
Latofat J. lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. She is 41 years old. She works as a journalist for the Hatlon newspaper. She is a university graduate with ten years of work experience. In order to improve her living conditions, she would like to receive a loan for the renovation of her apartment. She plans to repay the loan in the next 6 months from her salary.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva volunteer.

Джориева Латофат жительница города Курган-Тюбе. Возраст 41 год. Работает журналистом в редакции газеты «Хатлон». Имеет высшее образование. Работает уже 10 лет. Для того , чтобы улучшить условия жизни она решила получить кредит и сделать ремонт в квартире. Погасить кредит ей позволит ее заработная плата в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.use: apartment renovation

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Mr D. is about fifty years old and lives in the Cité Lamy neighborhood in Thiès. With help from his son, who lives abroad, he managed to create a business. For six years, he's been buying goods in Rosso (Mauritania) and reselling them to the local merchants as well as to his neighbors. With this loan, he would like to increase his working capital.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer.

mr D. est un quinquagénaire qui habite au quartier cité lamy de thies.avec l'aide de sonfils qui vit à l'étranger il a pu démarrer son ptit commerce depuis plus de six ans .son activité consiste à aller à rosso pour s'approvisionner pour venir revendre ses marchandises aux commerçants de la place mais aussi à ses voisins.avec ce pret il veut renforcer davantage son fonds de roulement .

loans.use: To increase the working capital of his business

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.es:
Rodolfo started the business because of his desire to get ahead and progress. Besides that, the company that distributes the products that he sells is a serious company that allows him to grow and develop. He needed to have an income to cover household expenses because he didn’t have a steady job and the expenses kept increasing because his children were growing, as was their need for food, clothing, education, etc. He started in March of 2004 as a consumer of some naturalist products due to some health issues that he had back then. Thanks to a friend who recommended the products to him and the results reflected in his improved health, he was convinced of them, became a distributor and began to offer the products to his neighbors and friends. Since then, thank God, he has done very well.

Rodolfo needs a loan for US$500, which he plans to repay in five months, to buy products that will allow him to fill his clients orders and thereby increase his earnings and commissions.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Rodolfo inició el negocio por las ganas de salir adelante y progresar, además de que la empresa que distribuye los productos que vendo es una empresa seria que le permite crecer y desarrollarse. El necesitaba tener un ingreso para solventar las necesidades de su hogar, ya que no tenía un empleo fijo y los gastos cada vez eran mas grandes ya que sus hijas iban creciendo y cada vez eran mayores sus necesidades de alimentación, ropa, estudio, etc. Comenzó en Marzo de 2004 como consumidor de unos productos naturistas por problemas de salud que tenía en aquel entonces y gracias a un amigo que le recomendó dichos productos los cuales se reflejaron con una mejoría de mi salud, quedo convencido de los mismos y se convirtio en un distribuidor, los cuales empezó a ofrecer con sus vecinos y amistades y desde entonces gracias a Dios le ha ido muy bien.

El necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 5 meses para comprar productos que le permitan surtir los pedidos de sus clientes y de esta forma incrementar sus ganancias y comisiones.

loans.use: Purchase product to sell

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S., 42, is a true entrepreneur and works with her husband, Huy Davroeun, 47, selling used clothes at the market to earn around $30 in revenue per day. This couple live in Siem Reap with one child. Every month she needs to spend around $75 on food and $100 on her child's education. To meet her customer's demands, she is requesting a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to add clothes to her inventory.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To add to her clothes inventory.

loans.name: Irma

texts.es: Irma tiene 28 años, es madre soltera, vive con su hija Velinda de 13 años en la Isla Tata Inti de los Uros.  Es una mujer muy emprendedora, desde hace 20 años ha trabajado en el negocio de la venta de artesanías como souvenirs, y la vestimenta de turistas con los trajes típicos de la zona, se dedica íntegramente a esta labor, ya que tuvo a su hija a muy temprana edad, no contaba con el apoyo de su pareja quien la abandonó al enterarse de su embarazo.  Ahora, su hija Velinda creció y es su principal fuente de apoyo, tanto de forma personal como en el negocio, juntas hacen que tenga éxito. Irma se siente feliz al contar con el apoyo de su hija y poder trabajar al lado de ella.  Su deseo es que su hija tenga un buen futuro, que constituya una familia con todo lo que ella le enseñó.  Con el dinero que Irma obtenga gracias al préstamo, comprará material para elaborar sus artesanías, tejidos, etc., y así aumentar su producción, y por ende sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Irma is 28 years of age. She is a single mother and lives in the Isla Tata Inti de los Uros with her daughter Velinda who is 13 years old. She is a very enterprising woman. For twenty years, she has worked in the business of selling handicrafts as souvenirs and typical clothing from the area for tourists. She wholly devotes herself to this work since she had her daughter at a very young age. She has not relied on the support of her former partner who abandoned her when he found out about her pregnancy. Now, her daughter Velinda has grown and is her main source of support, both personally and in her work. Together they have made it so she has been successful. Irma feels happy, counting on the support of her daughter and being able to work alongside her. Her hope is that her daughter has a good future with a family with everything she that she has taught her. With the money Irma receives thanks to the loan, she will buy materials to make her handicrafts, textiles, etc., and, that way, increase her production and, ultimately, her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials to make her handicrafts

loans.name: Marian Celestin

texts.en:
Marian Celestin N. is a 51-year-old married woman with one child. She is very hard-working, and she is committed to providing financial support for her family through her entrepreneurial skills. To that end, she has a business whereby she trades charcoal and maize in her neighborhood. She explains that charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in nearly every Ghanaian home. Marian obtains her supply of charcoal and maize from the surrounding villages of Jamani in the Eastern region of Ghana, and then she sells such charcoal and maize at retail prices to her customers.

She is currently seeking a loan to increase her inventory by purchasing charcoal and maize in bulk. In turn, she hopes that the loan will enable her to increase her savings in such a way that she can pay for her family's living expenses.

Marian is a member of the community group known as the Knowledge Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each others' loans as social collateral to ensure that their respective loans are promptly repaid. Her picture was taken at one of her group's meetings.

loans.use: The increase her inventory by purchasing a bulk supply of charcoal and maize.

loans.name: Nikolay

texts.en: Nikolai is married and has one baby daughter. He co-owns a furniture business. This is a retail business. They rent space in a store and put the furniture to be sold there. He has been in this business for two years. The business has grown rapidly because the furniture he sells is in high demand. Today, the gross income is 70,000 UAH a month; net profit is 7,000 UAH per month. Being very entrepreneurial in nature, Nikolay sees the potential for business growth. He would like to rent space in another store and open a second location. He needs a loan of 5,000 UAH. Nikolay hopes that additional income would finally allow him to purchase an apartment for his family.

loans.use: To pay rent for a second business location

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es:
La señora Filomena M., tiene 36 años, esta casada con Blasido Lopez, tienen 4 niños menores, todos dependientes de ellos. Ellos tienen este negocio en un barrio  de  la ciudad de Ypané, que es donde viven.
Ellos proveen de alimentos, materiales de limpieza, productos básicos de la canasta familiar a sus vecinos. Ellos se levantan muy temprano para ir al Mercado de Abasto, lugar donde compran todo lo necesario para surtir la despensa, a su llegada ya están esperando los vecinos ansiosos para comprar los productos, ya que es el único almacén cercano de la zona. Con este negocio salen adelante ella y sus hijos, todos estudian, y tienen buena atención, el sueño de la señora Filomena es tener una máquina para cortar carne, de esta manera  va a expandir su negocio, además de esto generar puestos de trabajo en la zona. Ella espera ansiosa el crédito.
texts.en:
Señora Filomena M. is 36 years old. She is married to Blasido Lopez. They have 4 small children, all dependant on them. They have thier business in a neighborhood of the city of Ypané, where they live. They provide food, cleaning supplies and basic household products to their neighbors. They rise very early to go to the Market of Abasto, where they buy all that is needed to supply their pantry. On their arrival the eager neighbors are already waiting to buy the products, since theirs is the only local store in the area. With this business she and her children do well. They all study, and receive good attention. The dream of Señora Filomena is to have a machine to cut meat. In this manner she is going to expand her business, as well as generate jobs in the area. She anxiously awaits the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, rice, noodles, milk, meat, eggs, yerba (herbal tea), bread etc.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a widow with two children. She lives in the town of Novaya Kahovka. Tatyana owns a little store and sells clothing in the local market. She has been in this trade for over seven years. Currently, Tatyana has 40,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her monthly income is about 2,000 – 3,000 Grivnas.  

Tatyana’s life motto is simple: “Integrity and treating people exactly as you would like to be treated.” Probably this is why she has succeeded in her business. However, Tatyana doesn’t want to stop at this stage. She wants to move on and focus her energy on growing and expanding, either by introducing new products or by increasing her sales area. That is why she is requesting this loan of 5,000 Grivnas and is hoping to repay it in eight months. Tatyana has a strong personality. She lost her husband two years ago and faced serious challenges in her business. However, she has recovered with the help of her son, who helped her out financially.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Mkasi

texts.en:
Mkasi has owned a small firewood store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to Sisi kwasisi loan group (Group code 2023).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50.Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Mkasi is 40 years old, married, and has three children: ages 14, 11 and 6.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Ziyadulla

texts.en:
T. Ziyadulla is 47 years old. He is a farmer who works on his land growing vegetables. He is assisted by his wife and elder sons. For the current planting season, he wants to plant high-quality potatoes, cucumbers and tomatoes so he can improve the quality of his harvest. With the loan money, Ziyadulla will be able to finance his current farming season to get a better harvest, enabling him to repay on schedule. The loan will greatly improve Ziyadulla’s income and his family's living standards. 
 

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of Alexander the Great's rule.  It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes,  is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and to a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Chimeddulam

texts.en:
Chimeddulam O. is the widowed mother of two living in Uvurhanghay, one of the southern provinces of Mongolia. Since 2000, she has been operating a retail business from a cargo container she owns that serves as a makeshift warehouse/store in Uugan, the biggest outdoor market in her area. She goes to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to buy car supplies, reselling them to local vehicle owners through her store. 

When she started her retail business, her working capital was 1 million Mongolian tugrigs (1,500 MNT=$1 USD). Now, it has increased to twice that amount. With her business profits, she has paid for her youngest son's college tuition, and with this loan, she will buy more car supplies to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy auto parts for the business.

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en: Mrs. Caridad S. is 61 years old and married to Asterio, a farmer. They have seven children, all of whom are married. Caridad started her business, a sari-sari store (mini grocery store), with a little capital she got from PMPC. She is a member in good standing and pays her dues promptly during their weekly center meetings. Recently, Caridad received another loan in the amount of PHP 10,000. She is very thankful to Paglaum and Kiva partners for the assistance, because it helps her a lot, especially in the daily financial needs of the family. She hopes to improve her family's status and continue the progress of her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her Mini Grocery Store

loans.name: Gladys Flavia

texts.es:
Gladys es socia del Banco Comunal Muchuy Huaraqac que significa abundancia en quechua.
Gladys es viuda, tiene 48 años y 3 hijos, Gladys tiene una tienda en casa de sus suegros en donde vende abarrotes en  general, bebidas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijas, también vende comida todos los días.
Gladys necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar y aceite.
Los sueños de Gladys son ahorrar para comprar su terreno y construir su casa, sus hijos sena profesionales.
texts.en:
Gladys is a member of the communal bank "Muchuy Huaraqac", which means "abundance" in Quechua. Gladys is a 48-year-old widow and has three children. Gladys has a store in the home of her in-laws, where she sells groceries and beverages with the help of her daughters. She also sells food every day. Gladys needs a loan of 1200 soles to buy rice, sugar and oil. Gladys dreams of saving money to buy land and build a house, and of her children becoming professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar and oil

loans.name: Francisca Maria

texts.es: la Señorita  Francisca Maria  es originaria de la comunidad de Juchanep a nueve Kilometros de la ciudad ella manifiesta que necesita un credito para ampliar su negocio ya que hoy tiene dos operarias y necesita contratar a otros dos personas  la Señorita ademas de trabajar en las artesania ser una persona profesiona  maestra de eduacion primaria, en la cual esta solicitando su plaza en el gobierno miestra que esto pasa ella se decia a la elaboracion y venta de su producto en los municipios de Totonicapan, Salcaj Quetzaltenango
texts.en:
Miss Francisca María is from the community of Juchanep, located nine kilometers from the city. She requests a loan to increase her business. She has two workers and needs to hire two more. Doña Francisca, apart from working in crafts, is a professional, an elementary school teacher presently requesting a position with the government. Meanwhile she manufactures and sells her products in the municipalities of Totonicapan, Salcaj Quetzaltenango.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase work capital

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: Otgonbayar B., a single mother, lives with her father and two children in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her 10-year-old son goes to a local high school and her 5-year-old daughter goes a local kindergarten. Otgonbayar has a small business making souvenirs. After taking a specialized course on "How to make souvenirs by pearls" in a local school, she launched her small business in handmade souvenirs. She usually makes various pearl-decorated souvenirs including artificial flowers, small paints, jewelries, etc. She sells her products at the local market. She requests a loan to order good quality pearls from Hoh hot, China, where many Mongolian small vendors travel and purchase various household goods. In the future, she would like to expand her business and open her own shop for exclusively pearl-inspired products.

loans.use: To buy pearls from Huh hot, China.

loans.name: Toeafe

texts.en:
Toeafe S., 30, is married with four children. She has 1 year of experience in her shop. She sells to the village people and public seven days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala.

She has no previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Toeafe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase freezers, tinned food, soap, etc.

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg N. is a 45-year-old widow who lives with her three sons and one daughter in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His children's ages range from 19 to 26. Oyunchimeg is a very entrepreneurial woman. Since 1992, she has been involved in many types of small business. Her first business was importing cheap clothes from Ereen, China, a border town from where many cheap Chinese products are imported. Since 2004, she has been selling cut wood to local carpenters. Within five years, she expanded the business, with her business capital increasing from 1,000,000 MNT to 3,400,000 MNT.

Now Oyunchimeg would like to open a small internet cafe to offer internet services and computer games to local people. She sees a great market opportunity as many local young people are really getting into internet surfing and computer games. She is committed to making the internet cafe a success as her private businesses are the sole source of family income. All of her children are top students at their respective high schools, and Oyunchimeg wants to make sure that they all continue their studies at the universities of their choice and pursue their dreams. She says that she works very hard to make all this come true.

Oyunchimeg is requesting a loan to purchase computers and internet access for her new internet cafe.

loans.use: To purchase computers and internet access for her internet cafe

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Señora Mariana sells cold drinks and clothing. In this photo she shows the few drinks left in her refrigerator following a heavy period of sales resulting from the Peruvian Independence Day celebrations in her neighborhood during the last week of July. Mariana is 53 years old and is married with three adult children. Mariana's husband works at the offices of the Pucallpa city government.

Mariana has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about six years and is a member of the communal bank "Nuevas Amigas" (“New Friends”). She used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in a small grocery shop that she had at that time.

Mariana plans to use this loan of 2,000 soles to invest in clothing which she will sell in the small communities along the Ucayali, the wiD. brown river which flows past the city of Pucallpa and joins the Amazon to the north. She will also use some of the loan to purchase beer and soda for her business selling cold drinks.

Mariana's goal is to re-establish her grocery shop. She also wants to maintain her business selling cold drinks. She is grateful for the financial assistance that she has received from Manuela Ramos. Working with the organization has also motivated her to keep moving forward with her business ventures.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell and also beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is 48 years old and married with four children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. Dorothy sells drinks and food items. She hopes for a loan amount of 70000 NGN to purchase more drinks and food items to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and food items to sell

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda is forty-eight years old. She is widowed and has given birth to six children, a son and five daughters, who are all in school. She works very hard to be able to provide for the family. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Konongo in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a baker. She bakes bread that she supplies to retailers, supermarket stores, and beverage sellers in her community. Matilda buys her raw materials in Kumasi at moderate prices. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour

loans.name: Exaltacion

texts.en:
Exaltacion B. is from the village of Bangko, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 64 years old and married with four grown children. To make a living, Exaltacion raises pigs for sale.  She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Exaltacion joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional pigs. Exaltacion is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feeds and medication. This will be her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feeds & medication

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 40 years old and already a widow.  Her husband died 14 years ago and she was left with three children.  Her eldest child is Roxanne- 18 years old, 3rd year college; Re-Anne-15 years old, 4th year high school student and the youngest is Rustom- 14 years old , 3rd year high school student. They are presently residing at San Francisco, Alicia, Isabela. Her sources of income are farming, direct selling, and an honorarium salary of PHP1,600.00 from their village.

She operates a village store and she can earn a weekly net income of PHP500-600.00.  She is now asking for financial support from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP7,000.00 that she can use for her store.  She hopes that the lenders will grant her loan for her to pursue her business plans.

loans.use: Additional Capital in her retail store

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen es una mujer que le sonríe a la vida a pesar de las múltiples dificultades que debió afrontar. Ella tiene 31 años y aunque está divorciada vive feliz con sus 2 hijas; Yurubi de 14 y Francesca que tiene 4 años. 

Cada día Carmen se levanta  temprano para atender a sus dos pequeñas hijas que son su adoración y sentido de vida, además debe cocinar rápidamente para los comensales que le compran sus ricos y diversos platos que ofrece cada día. Si hay algún pedido, no hay problema, porque ella misma los entrega hasta donde se lo pidan sus vecinos, conocidos o amigos. Las comidas que vende son muy demandadas, pues a diario innova en las artes culinarias que aprendió de su madre, y los secretos de sus platos no los devela por nada del mundo, así tiene a sus clientes más que satisfechos por el sabor y por los bajos precios que ofrece. 

Desde hace un año, todos los días de la semana, ofrece una delicia diferente para los paladares que la consumen, este negocio le gusta porque ha crecido mucho en poco tiempo y obtiene buenas ganancias, para lograrlo sus hijas también le ayudan en sus ratos libres porque la principal preocupación de Carmen es que sus dos hijas estudien y tengan una profesión, porque ella no lo logró estudiar una. 
Además, su ex esposo la ayuda económicamente en la crianza de sus hijas y para el futuro tiene planeado aperturar  un restaurante donde ella sea la administradora.

Aunque este es su noveno préstamo con MFP,  Carmen promete una vez más ser puntual y cumplir con sus pagos. Ella tiene la esperanza de crecer y lo logrará con mucha dedicación, además está muy satisfecha con el trabajo de su banco comunal porque está compuesto por mujeres luchadoras como ella. El dinero que ahora solicita lo destinará a la compra de mercadería para abastecerse mejor en la cocina, donde prepara las diversas comidas que comercializa .
texts.en:
Carmen is a woman who smiles at life despite the many difficulties she has had to face. She is 31 years old, divorced, and lives happily with her two daughters – Francesca (age 14) and Yurubi (age 4).

Every day Carmen wakes up early to care for her two young daughters, who provide her with a reason for living and are the objects of her adoration. Afterwards, she must quickly prepare meals for her patrons who purchase the rich and diverse dishes she offers on a daily basis. She fulfills any request without objection, because her customers also ask her to deliver meals to neighbors, acquaintances, or friends. Her dishes are in high demand. Carmen’s ability to create a new dish every day was something she learned from her mother. Even though she keeps her recipes a secret, she manages to satisfy her customers by providing flavorful dishes and selling them at a low price.

Since she offers a different dish every day of the week, her business has grown rapidly and continues to generate good earnings. Her daughters help out in their spare time, but Carmen prefers that they focus on their studies so that they can pursue a profession, an opportunity that she did not have. Her ex-husband provides financial support in raising her daughters. Carmen hopes to manage her own restaurant in the future.

Even though she is taking her ninth loan with MFP, Carmen once again promises to be punctual and make her payments on time. She hopes to continue growing and succeeding. She is happy to be working with her Communal Bank because the other women in her group are fighters just like her. With the money she is requesting, she will buy merchandise to restock her pantry so that she can continue preparing meals to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for preparing meals

loans.name: On's Group

texts.en: This is a small loan request for two borrowers. The leader, Mrs. On I., age 36, has been a garment worker since 2002. On I. lives with her three teenage children, one of whom works sewing clothes, while the other two attend school. To help meet the family's needs, her husband drives a motorbike taxi. On I. requests a loan to invest in a fishing business. The other borrower, Mrs. Bun M., is a fresh fish seller who is requesting a loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To invest in a fishing business

loans.name: Elia Del Carmen

texts.es: Elia del Carmen S. P.  de 49 años de edad, reside en Ilopango en el departamento de San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres pequeños hijos todos menores de edad. Elia posee una pequeña tienda en su hogar, negocio el cual ella desea ampliarlo y poder surtirlo, ya que este le permite ayudarle a su esposo con todos los gastos del hogar. Ella solicita un préstamo, el cual le permita realizar el sueño de mejorar su negocio, surtirla con más productos como pan, sodas, golosinas, entre otras cosas más, ya que para ella su tienda representa una gran ayuda, la cual le permite brindarles todo lo necesarios a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Elia del Carmen Sanchez Perez is 49 years old and resides in Llopango in the department of San Salvador. She lives together with her husband and their three small children. In her home, she operates a small store, which she desires to expand and to be able to stock, since it enables her to help her husband with the domestic expenses. She is requesting a loan, which will allow her to realize her dream of improving her business, stocking it with more products such as bread, soda, and candy, among other things. For Elia, her store represents a great help, which enables her to provide everything necessary to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase perishable food products

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: K. Godfrey is 48 years old and married with four children. He owns a retail shop and he has been in business for over ten years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as maize flour. His dream is to improve upon his business and to become a major supplier of maize flour in his business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items to sell, such as maize flour.

loans.name: Juana Natividad

texts.es:
La socia Juana es natural de la ciudad de Urcos de la provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” de la Asociación Arariwa. Nuestra socia Juana tiene 52 años, es casada y tiene tres hijos y dos ya no depende de ella pero el ultimo hijo llamado Joel tiene 12 años y estudia en el colegio.

La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como cocinar para su menor hijo y lo deja la comida para que él se sirva al medio día. La socia después de hacer sus actividades del hogar tiene que trabajar para Municipalidad de Urcos en el sector de limpieza publica, su labor es limpiar calles, plazas y parques de la cuidad de Urcos. La socia nos cuenta que tiene un pequeño taller de artesanía donde trabajo su hija Rosmery. Ya son varios años que tienen el negocio y les ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que ponen en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que requiere el préstamo para comprar más material como lana, telas, hilos y cuero para crear más artesanía. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Juana is a native of the city of Urcos in the Quispicanchis province of the department of Cusco. She belongs to the communal bank "Qori Orcco" which is part of the Arariwa Association. Juana is 52 years old, married, and has 3 children. Two of the children are no longer dependent but the last son, named Joel, is 12 years old and studies in school. Juana gets up very early to complete her household work such as cooking for her youngest son; she leaves the meal for him to eat at midday. Later, after she finishes her activities in the home, she has to work for the Municipality of Urcos in the public cleaning department where she cleans streets, plazas and parks in the city of Urcos. She tells us that she has a small handicraft workshop where her daughter Rosmery works. She has had this business for some years now, and it has gone very well, thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is a hardworking and enterprising mother who needs a loan to buy more material such as wool, fabrics, thread and leather to make more crafts. Juana is grateful for the opportunity provided through these means, and pledges to make the payments according to the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more raw materials such as wool, fabric, thread and leather

loans.name: Orepa

texts.en:
Orepa V. is 25 and married with 3 children (ages 2-months - 6).  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Orepa has 6 years of experience in this business.  Orepa needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 355 tala or US $148 per week) to make improvements to her house.

In 2008, Orepa joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Orepa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Orepa V. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Agossoussi

texts.fr: Née en 1968 à TOFFO à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique, T. Agossoussi y vit depuis sa naissance. Agossoussi est mariée à HOUNGNINOU Alphonse et est mère de deux enfants, mais a un autre enfant à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Agossoussi vit seule avec ses enfants et assure toute seule leurs charges. Pour subvenir à tous ses besoins et assurer l'entretien et l'éducation des enfants, Agossoussi vend du maïs à Sey à Allada. Parallèlement à cette activité, Agossoussi vend de la farine de manioc communément appelée "gari", ce qui lui permet d'avoir une autre source de revenu. Agossoussi s'approvisionne au marché de Sey et de Houègbo à Allada. Agossoussi mène cette activité depuis 24 ans et a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Agossoussi a bien remboursé les deux crédits. Agossoussi ambitionne agrandir davantage son activité pour mieux faire face à sa clientèle et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges. Mais par manque de moyens financiers pour atteindre ses objectifs, Agossoussi sollicite un troisème prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic, Agossoussi T. has lived there since her birth. She is married to Alphonse HOUNGNINOU, and is the mother of two children with another child under her care. All the children are educated. Agossoussi lives alone with her children and is their sole provider. To meet all her needs and ensure proper care and education for her children, Agossoussi sells corn in the Sey area of Allada. Additionally, she sells cassava flour – commonly called ‘gari’ – which provides her with another source of income. Agossoussi gets her supplies from local markets in Allada (Sey and Honègbo). Agossoussi has been running this business for 24 years and has already been granted two loans by ALIDé, both of which were fully reimbursed. She wants to expand her activities to better meet her customer’s expectations and generate enough revenue to meet her needs. As she lacks the financial means to reach her objectives, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 10 bags of corn

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina A. is 31 years old and married without children. Her husband is a business man and he also supports the home. Faustina sells drinks and juice at retail prices to her customers.  She hopes to expand her business to include the sale of groceries in the future. Faustina hopes for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks and juice to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and juice to sell.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
31-year-old Venus N. is a married woman with a four-year-old child. She lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur and owns a farm there. Aside from rice farming, she also runs a stall in the market where she sells pork and cow’s meat.

Venus shared that she is in need of additional capital for her farm. She applied to CEVI and requested a loan of Php 6,000. She said she would use this loan to buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs she needs for her rice farm.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Shugar

texts.en:
Shugar G. is a member of Bombong Center in Rizal South Branch (RSB). She is a 29-year-old mother married to Jason and blessed with one son. She was encouraged to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines because the institution helps women show their skills by lending them working capital for a business as a micro-entrepreneur.

She marks the day that she joined ASHI in 2006: she began to dream, hope, and find a way to get out of poverty. To supply additional income for her family, Shugar is interested in continuing her fishing business.

Shugar would like to receive a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase raw materials like nets, bamboo, rope, and a new fish cage. As a proud member of ASHI, Shugar is thankful to obtain secured capital to support her goals in life. Her long-term goals are to build a profitable fishing business, send all of her children to college, and invest in her home. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is dedicated to expand her fishing business and determined to achieve financial stability for her family.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like nets, bamboo, rope, and a new fish cage.

loans.name: Gladys Lucia

texts.es: LA SEÑORA GLADYS ESTA CASADA Y VIVE EN LA ZONA OBISPO INDABURO, TIENE 3 HIJOS SU ESPOSO ES TECNICO Y AMBOS LOGRARON SALIR ADELANTE A BASE D. ESFUERZO, HOY ELLOS VIVEN COMODAMENTE EN UN DEPARTAMENTO QUE ESTA EN ANTICRETICO Y ESTAN CON EL DESEO D. QUE MAS ADELANTE PUEDAN COMPRAR UNA CASA PROPIA PARA DEJAR A SUS HIJOS, LA SEÑORA TIENE LA PENSION HACE DOS AÑOS Y LA GENTE QUE  ALMUERZA AHÍ DICE QUE LA SEÑORA GLADYS TIENE MUY BUEN SAZON EN SU COMIDA Y PREPARA DELICIOSOS PLATOS ES JOVEN MUY TRABAJADORA QUIERE MEJORAR LA CALIDAD D. VIDA D. TODA SU FAMILIA , ESTA MUY CONTENTA D. TENER UNA TASA KIVA Y MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Gladys is married and lives in the Obispo Indaburo area with her three children and her husband, who works as a technician. Both of them were able to get ahead by making a great effort, and today they live comfortably in a rented apartment. Further down the track they would like to buy their own house to leave to their children. Gladys is a young and very hard working woman who wants to improve the quality of life for all of her family. She started her restaurant two years ago and her customers say that the food she cooks is flavoursome and delicious. Gladys is very happy to have a Kiva loan and is very grateful to Kiva and their field partner Emprender for the trust they have placed in her by approving her loan.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
Nighat is a very talented and hardworking lady. She embroiders dresses and sells them in boutiques. Her work attracts more customers so the owners of boutiques come to her with orders. She earns approximately $60 a month, which is a big source of income for the family. 

She has six children: three sons and three daughters. All of her kids are enrolled in school. 

Her husband operates a wood-selling business in the community. He also goes to different areas on his donkey cart to deliver his customers' orders. He has been in this business for over ten years. 

Nighat is applying for the first time for a loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan) to purchase embroidery items in bulk (beads, colored threads, sketches and fabric) to expand her embroidery business.

loans.use: Purchase items for making embroidered dresses

loans.name: Lucinda's Group

texts.es:
“Por primera vez me he prestado plata D. la Unidad D. Micro finanzas Asociación Arariwa”

Zoraida, tiene 27 años, es casada  y tiene una hija llamada Katherine D. cuatro años, es natural D. la Comunidad D. Huayocari del distrito D. Huallabamba D. la provincia D. Urubamba departamento del Cusco. 

Zoraida  nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Virgen del Carmen”  somos 11 integrantes (9 mujeres y 2 varones) y me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi actividad comercial.  
Zoraida  es empleada del restaurante en la “Hacienda D. Huayocari”. Ya son 5 años que trabaja en el restaurante y le va muy bien. Ella requiere el préstamo para alquilar un terreno en la comunidad D. Huayocari para sembrar  productos como por ejemplo cebollas, zanahorias, etc. 

Zoraida quiere aprender a ser responsable con el dinero y saber invertir bien el dinero en su negocio y por ese motivo ingreso a  formar parte del banco comunal. 

Las reuniones D. los socios son cada treinta días en la casa D. la socia Mary luz que muy amablemente les presta un espacio D. su tienda. 

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo venta D. abarrotes, venta D. tortas, venta D. chicha, venta D. verduras y venta D. carne y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo empleada D. restaurante, cocinera, portador del camino Inca y chofer.

La ciudad D. Huayocari se encuentra a una hora y treinta minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco en carro.
texts.en:
“For the first time, I have been lent money from the Asociación Arariwa microfinance entity.” Zoraida, age 27, is married and has a four year old daughter named Katherine. She is from the Huayocari community in the Huallabamba district, Urubamba province, Cusco department. Zoraida tells us that there are 11 members (nine women and two men) in the Virgen del Carmen Communal Bank. They elected her to represent the communal bank, and to tell about her commercial activity. Zoraida is employed by the Hacienda D. Huayocari restaurant. She has worked in the restaurant for five years, and it is going very well for her. She needs the loan to rent a piece of land in the Huayocari community. She will plant products like onions and carrots, etc. Zoraida wants to learn to be responsible with money. She wants to know how to invest her money well in her business. That is why she joined and became part of the communal bank. The members meetings are every 30 days at Mary Luz’s house. She is a member who kindly lends them a space in her store. Most of the members are merchants who sell groceries, sell cakes, sell “chicha” (a drink maD. from corn), sell vegetables, or sell meat. Other members proviD. services like working in a restaurant, cooking, transportation along the Incan trail, or driving. The city of Huayocari is one hour and thirty minutes by car from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Zoraida needs the loan to rent a piece of land in the Huayocari community to plant products like onions and carrots, etc.

loans.name: Maria Cecilia

texts.es:
En la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca encontramos el banco comunal Fuerza del Mañana integrado por mujeres decididas a salir adelante junto a su familia, esta ciudad es considerada por todos los  ecuatorianos como una de  las más bella y limpia  del país, Cuenca fue declarada Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad por la UNESCO en diciembre de 1999 y dentro de sus principales atractivos turísticos  son las edificaciones del centro histórico, la belleza natural de su entorno y las artesanías que encontramos hechas en distintos materiales propios de la región.

La señora  María S. tiene 43 años y es una socia nueva del banco comunal  Fuerza del Mañana, vive  en unión libre con su pareja con quien han concebido dos hijos el mayor de 15 años y un bebe de un año aproximadamente,  su esposo  trabaja en una carpintería mientras que ella se dedica al cuidado de su familia y los quehaceres del hogar, viven arrendando y su mayor sueño es tener su casa propia.

Este es su primer ciclo  y fue motivada por una amiga que forma parte de éste banco, con  el dinero de su crédito va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, atún, sal, artículos de limpieza y cuidado personal  y más productos de primera necesidad  para su hogar.
texts.en:
The communal bank Fuerza del Mañana is found in the capital city of Cuenca. It is made up of women who are determined to get ahead together with their families. This city is considered one on the most beautiful and cleanest in the country by all Ecuadorians. Cuenca was declared a World Heritage city by UNESCO in December of 1999. Among its main tourist attractions are the buildings in the historic center, the natural beauty of its surroundings and the crafts we find that are made from different materials from the area. Mrs. María S. is 43 years old and she is a new member of the communal bank Fuerza del Mañana. She lives with her common law husband with whom she has two children, the oldest a 15 years old and a year-old baby approximately. Her husband works in a carpenter’s shop while she takes care of the family and the household chores. They are renters and their biggest dream is to have their own house. This is her first loan cycle. A friend who is part of this bank encouraged her to join. She is going to buy rice, sugar, oil, tuna fish, salt, cleaning products and personal care items and more basic essentials for her home with the money from the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, oil, tuna fish, salt, cleaning products and personal care items and more basic essentials

loans.name: Mungunzul

texts.en: Mungunzul G. is 20 years old. She got married in August 2009 and lives with her husband in a traditional Mongolian housing tent, called a ger, neighboring her mother's home. Their life condition is good and their furniture is quite new, because the couple just got married. The husband works as a porter at Narantuul market, loading and hauling luggage and goods.  He earns 200,000 MNT wage per month. They have not planned to have a baby yet. Her mother, G., has been running a shoe sales business for a long time and purchased a stall at the market for her daughter, Mungunzul. Mungunzul has not got much business experience yet, so she asks help from her mother. This time Mungunzul is trying to go to Erlian, a Chinese border city and trading center, to purchase products herself in order to gain experience and run her business independently. Mungunzul is a very modest girl. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase kids' sports shoes and summer shoes.

loans.use: To purchase kids shoes to sell.

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
E. Marhabo has operated a clothing sales business in the market of  “Somon-bozor” in Khujand for 6 years. Enterprising and hardworking, Marhabo has succeeded in her business due to experience and a joyful spirit. With the profits of her business, she is supporting her family which consists of her husband and two children. Marhabo is currently seeking a loan of $800 to expand the range of her clothing. She wants to expand her business: an achievement that will bring a better quality of life for her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase stock of new kids' clothing for kids for the summer season.

loans.name: Kokoe Hemefa

texts.en: Madame Kokoe Hemefa M. is 32 years old and works in Lome, Togo. She sells used clothing in Lome's largest outdoor market. She is experienced in this sort of business and has been working in it for about 10 years. She is married to a sound technician and they have two children. Madame M. is requesting a loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA. This will allow her to purchase better and more diverse merchandise to satisfy her customers and increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase two large bags of used clothing

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is widowed and has five children who all go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Esther owns a store at her home in in Kawempe from which she sells charcoal. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans which transport the charcoal from Luwero. She would like to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Esther doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work. She has been in this charcoal business for a long time. Besides this charcoal business she doesn’t have any other side income. She sells both on the retail and wholesale markets and works seven days a week. Esther's business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She aspires to increase the size of her business and start selling only on the wholesale market. Esther joined MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She resides in and owns a four-room house and her family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcaol.

loans.name: Martires

texts.es:
la sra. Martires G. tiene 44 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Orlando Pavon con quien tiene tres hijos que estan en la escuela, Martires radica junto a su familia en su casa ubicada en Jicaro Galan de Nacaome Valle, ahi viven desde hace unos 17 años.
Martires se dedica al negocio de pulperia, siempre a querido tener su propio negocio, Martires en su pulperia vende abarroteria como ser: manteca, jabon, azucar, harina de maiz, cloro, desinfectantes, cereal, refrescos, pan, huevos, leche, sardinas, pastas, chiles, tortillas y otra variedad de productos.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia al por mayor y asi surtir mas su pulperia.
su deseo es que sus hijos se graduen de sus estudios y que sean buenos profesionales y hombres de bien.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mártires G., 44, is married to Mr. Orlando Pavón; they have three children who are in school. Mártires and her family live in their home located in Jicaro Galan de Nacome Valle; they have lived there for 17 years. Mártires has a grocery store where she stocks such things as: lard, soap, sugar, corn flour, chlorine bleach, disinfectants, cereal, beverages, bread, eggs, milk, sardines, pasta, chilies, tortillas and a large variety of other products. The loan will be used to buy more merchandise at wholesale thus stocking her store better. Her wish is that her children graduate from school and that they become good professionals and upstanding citizens.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sardines, toilet paper, soups, lard, cooking oil, soaps, pastas, salt, spices, batteries, razors, beans, tortillas, sugar, rice, bread, cookies, beverages.

loans.name: Mrs. Phally Ouch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank consists of fifteen people who live in Tang Ruessei village in Takeo province. Mrs. Phally O. is a village bank president who was born in 1973, selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan in various ways.

She is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Ren Son, is a soya-bean seller door-to-door. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production Mrs. Phally O. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of six children, two of whO. are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other three are enrolled in local school, and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda N. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 30 years old. Roda is married and has two children, aged 3 and 1. To make a living, Roda raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Roda says she works hard to provide for her family and save for her children's future education.

Roda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Roda is requesting a new loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en:
Jameela is a resident of Borewala, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. She lives in the area of 435/EB in a two-roomed brick house with her family. 

Jameela is a very good-natured woman who has spent most of her life in serving for her family and relatives. Her family and relatives respect her a lot for her caring and supportive nature towards them. Her husband's name is M. J.. He is a driver by trade. He has been in this profession for the last several years. Earlier, he drove for someone else and then he started driving for himself. Since beginning his own driving business up to now, he gained experience on rickshaw. He purchased a rickshaw five years ago from the savings. He provides transport services to his customers and makes an income for his family.  

Jameela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. With the loan amount, her husband will repair his rickshaw. The rickshaw engine is creating problem and, if it never gets repaired, it will seize and put M. into trouble with his business.  

Jameela is hopeful that, by repairing the rickshaw, her husband will continue his driving for a longer period and able to make a good profit as well.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Yessica Patricia

texts.es:
Yessenia de 36 años, tiene una pequeña papelería en la parte delantera de su casa, vive en el Paraíso de Guayaquil (zona periurbana, con caminos de tierra y las casas están ubicadas en montañas). 

Inicio su negocio hace tres años atrás desde que su mama con uno de sus hermanos le comenzaron a enviar dinero del extranjero  para invertir en una papelería. Poco a poco con esfuerzo ha podido incrementar su pequeña papelería. Por un tumor que tenia paralizo un poco sus ventas hace dos años pero ya esta recuperada y lista para tener su papelería bien surtida. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una copiadora para dar otros servicios a sus clientes. En el futuro quiere incrementar la papelería y dar un buen servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Yessenia is 36 years old and runs a small paper store in the front part of her home; she lives in Paraiso de Guayaquil (a semi-urban area with dirt streets and houses situated in the mountains).

She started her business 3 years ago when her mother and one of her brothers started sending her money from abroad to invest in the store.  Little by little, she has been able to grow her small paper store.  She had a tumor 2 years ago which slowed her ability to grow the business but now she has recovered and is ready to stock her store.

She will use the loan to buy a copier to provide other services to her customers.  In the future, she would like to grow the paper store and give great service to her clients.

loans.use: Copiers

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce K. is 30 years old, widowed, and has one child who attends school.  She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock fish, onions, and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en: Seraphine is 24 years old. She is married and has two children between the ages of one and three. None of her children go to school. Her husband works as a motorbike and bicycle mechanic. Seraphine has been selling sugar, rice and bicycle spare parts for five years. With this loan she will increase her inventory. She will save some of the profits in a bank and use the rest to renovate her house. She says that her business is valuable because it helped her purchase land for crop cultivation. Her dream is to have a bigger business.

loans.use: to buy more rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Herdenia

texts.en:
Herdenia A. is from Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Herdenia is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Herdenia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from dealing in cosmetics, lotions & deodorant products from NATASHA & AVON  in the local community. Herdenia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Herdenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Herdenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Herdenia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Herdenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Christian Village, Wao, Lanao del Sur

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying clothes for sale

loans.name: Maria Francisca

texts.es:
Doña María, reside en Lolotiquillo, departamento de Morazán, tiene 47 años de edad, se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y al cultivo de maíz, vive con sus cuatro hijos y tres nietos, su negocio es la crianza de cerdos y cuando estos han engordado los lleva a vender y con la ayuda de sus hijos y nietos desarrolla la siembra de maíz, estas son sus fuentes de ingreso con las que cuenta para salir de sus gastos y comprar la alimentación para toda la familia.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de cerdos, ya que desea invertir comprando algunos cerditos para engordar y comenzar el proceso para luego venderlos, con este préstamo podrá obtenerlos y seguir en el negocio.
Su mayor deseo es ayudar a sus nietos para que estudien y puedan prepararse desarrollando su vida en un mejor ambiente.
texts.en:
María lives in Lolotiquillo, Morazán department.  She is 47 years old and raises pigs and grows corn.  She lives with her four children and three grandchildren.  Her business is raising pigs.  When they have been fattened up she takes them to sell. Her children and grandchildren help her with the corn farming.  These are the sources of income she counts on to cover expenses and buy food for the entire family.

She is asking for a loan to buy pigs because she wants to invest in buying a few piglets to raise and start the process leading to their sale.  With the loan she will be able to do this and stay in business.

Her greatest desire is to help her grandchildren study and prepare themselves to develop their lives in a better environment.

loans.use: To buy pigs.

loans.name: Marie Grace

texts.en:
Marie Grace is 32 years old and married.   She has one child who is one year old.  Marie Grace has been selling clothes for about three years.  Her business hours are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day except Saturday.

Marie Grace requests this loan through the Kiva partner Vision Finance Company to purchase more clothes to sell.  The extra income generated from the loan will help her reinvest in the future and continue to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is divorced and has three children. She sells fruits and plantain at Elmina, which she has been doing for twenty years. Mary uses her income to see to the well being of her family.  Mary will use the loan to purchase more fruits for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more fruits for sale.

loans.name: Petrona De Los Angeles

texts.es: Petrona tiene 27 años, su actividad es la venta de quesillos, hace más de 4 años  que tiene este negocio, pues todos los días de semana tiene que salir a los colegios para vender sus productos. Ella siempre está pendiente de sus 2 hijos menores de edad que son muy importantes, es por eso que se esfuerza por mantener este negocio que es el que le genera ganancias a su hogar. El crédito es para la compra de tortillas, quesillos, bolsas, servilletas entre otras cosas. El sueño de Petrona es heredarles el negocio a sus hijos para que tenga un medio de supervivencia.
texts.en:
Petrona, 27, sells cheese.  She’s had this business for over 4 years.  She goes out every day of the week to sell at schools.  She is always watchful of her two small children who are very important to her.  Because of this she strives to keep the business which is what generates income for her home.

She will use the loan to buy tortillas, cheese, bags and napkins, among others.  Petrona’s dream is to leave the business to her children so that they will have a means of supporting themselves.

loans.use: To buy tortillas, cheese, bags and napkins, among others.

loans.name: Ligia Maria

texts.es:
Ligia madre soltera, mujer emprendedora, trabajadora ha salido adelante con sus hijos y tiene proyecto de mejorara su vivienda, cumplir con su sueño de que sus hijos se preparen y en ámbito laboral que ella tenga sus tramos en el cual tenga uno de abarrote y el otro una peluquería, ya que tiene conocimiento en el ramo de la belleza. Como fuente de trabajo tiene su pulpería que su hijo le apoya en la venta, también la peluquería y alquila cuartos para universitarios.  Inicio su pulpería con fondo propios y poco apoco ha ido aumentando sus ventas. 
El préstamo que solicitad es para agrandar su inventario con la compra de nuevas y variada mercadería como: artículos escolares, bisutería, perfumes, granos básicos, productos enlatados, bebidas y otros. Agradece a la financiera por el apoyo a su desarrollo como micro empresaria que es.
texts.en: Ligia is a single mother. She is a very hardworking and enterprising woman, who has provided for her children and now has a project to improve their home. Her dream is to ensure her children have a good education and, in terms of work, for one to have a grocery shop and the other a hairdressers. Ligia herself has a small grocery shop and a hairdressers. She also rents out rooms to university students. She opened her grocery shop with her own savings and gradually increased her sales over time. She will use the loan to broaden the range of products she sells, to include new and varied merchandise such as: school stationery; inexpensive jewellery; perfumes; basic cereals; canned produce; and drinks. She is very grateful for the financial support, to help develop her small enterprise.

loans.use: compra de productos

loans.name: Tété

texts.fr: Monsieur Tété habite quartier Adidogomé. Il est marié et père de  2 enfants. Il  est âgé de 62 ans. Il exerce comme activité la vente de carte de recharge et téléphone. Il  a commencé  en 2006 et s’approvisionne à la direction Togocel, Togo Telecom et Moov. Ensuite il revend dans une cabine à côté de Boukarou.   Il demande un crédit  pour  acheter  200 cartes Togocel, 80 cartes Illico Togo télécom et 150 cartes Moov.
texts.en: Monsieur Tété lives in the Adidogomé area. He is a married father of two. He is 62 years old. He makes his living by selling phone cards and phones. He started in 2006 and stocks up with Togocel, Togo Télécom and Moov. He then sells in a booth next to Boukarou. He is seeking a loan to buy 200 Togocel cards, 80 Togo Télécom cards, and 150 Moov cards.

loans.use: to buy phone cards

loans.name: Joel Adalberto

texts.es:
Joel de 26 años, es un joven trabajador que desde muy pequeño aprendió a reparar bicicletas. Poco a poco fue incursionando en el mercado de bicicletas hasta ahora que tiene un pequeño taller de reparación de bicicletas. 

En la actualidad trabaja desde las 08h00am hasta las 20h00pm todos los días. Repara los tubos, frenos da mantenimiento a las bicicletas etc. Tiene muchas aspiraciones con su taller ya que desea con el préstamo comprar tubos, cadenas aceite. En el futuro quiere que su negocio aumente con mas clientela.
texts.en:
26 year-old Joel is a hard-working young man who learned to repair bicycles at a very young age.  He gradually broke into the bicycle market and now has a small workshop where he repairs bicycles.

Joel currently works from 8.00am to 8.00pm every day.  He repairs inner tubes and brakes, and does maintenance work on bicycles.  Joel has a lot of aspirations for his workshop.  He would like to use his loan to buy inner tubes, chains and oil.  In the future, he would like his business to grow and have more customers.

loans.use: to buy inner tubes and chains

loans.name: Dzingenhamo Group

texts.en:
Florence D., in the middle of the front row, is the leader of the Dzingenhamo group. Florence is a 48-year-old cross-border trader who imports blankets, clothes and pots for resale.  Her husband works as a driver at a local firm. They have 4 children and two other dependants. One child aged 15 is still attending school. Her business operations at times dwindle as a result of her debtors failing to pay on time. 

Florence will buy more clothing and blankets for resale with the loan she has requested through MicroKing. She will also purchase airtime cards for resale. She strongly believes that her livelihood will be improved by the loan as she sees herself acquiring better household assets. Florence wishes to own her business premises in the future as she is currently renting. She is very thankful to MicroKing and Kiva for the loan facility that will assist in increasing her productivity.

loans.use: to buy more blankets and clothes for resale

loans.name: Lanier De Jesús

texts.es:
Lanier, tiene 28 años de edad, es originario de la comunidad La Pita, ubicada en el municipio Miraflor, Estelí, de oficio agricultor, esta casado tiene dos hijos, lleva 6 años dedicándose a la siembra de hortaliza de forma independiente. Empezó con ayuda de su papa a la edad de 10 años, su padre le enseñaba a preparar la tierra, pero difícil situación económica le impidieron seguir con sus estudios, se tuvo que dedicar tiempo completo a trabajar para poder subsistir y ayudar a su familia.
Solicita el préstamo para mantenimiento, compra de insumos y pago de mano de obra de siembra de tomate. Le ayudara a aumentar su producción, sacar mejor rendimiento de su cosecha de tomate.
